title: ASX advances as trade worries ease, Santos climbs
text:
The US agreed to suspend a tariff hike on $US250 million of Chinese goods that was scheduled for this week. In exchange, China will buy up to $US50 billion of goods from American farmers. The deal has yet to be officially signed.

"The temporary truce does not clear the cloud of trade policy uncertainty that has been affecting the global economy, and thus could continue to have an impact on investment and supply chains’ diversification plans," noted Citi's economics team.

"Intellectual property protection, technology transfers, and industrial subsidies will remain major points of contention through the next phases of negotiations," they said.

The news that the UK and the European Union have entered into three days of intensive talks in Brussels, signalling that a deal on Britain's divorce from Europe could be in sight, helped the pound post its biggest two-day gain in a decade and UK bank stocks to soar.

Intellectual property protection, technology transfers, and industrial subsidies will remain major points of contention.

In Australian corporate dealmaking, Santos shares rose 5.7 per cent to $7.85 after the firm told investors that it will buy ConocoPhillips’ northern Australia interests for Darwin LNG, Bayu-Undan, Barossa and Poseidon for $US1.39 billion plus a $75 million contingent payment subject to a final investment decision on Barossa.

The deal will be funded through existing cash resources and newly committed debt and is expected to increase earnings per share in 2020 by 15 per cent.

"Santos is a natural acquirer of those assets," said Mr Sala Tenna. "It does fit well with their profile."

"The more diversification they can build, the better," he said. "I am nervous on GLNG and the ability of those wells to produce what they need."

Other energy stocks advancing included Woodside, up 2.5 per cent at $32 and Origin Energy, up 1.8 per cent at $8.01.

Broadly, Mr Sala Tenna said "we are starting to see buying in some of the counter-cyclical value stocks and Brexit stocks are starting to reverse a bit".

British-focused, Australian-listed, CYBG shot up 12.1 per cent to $2.41 in Australian trading on Monday.

Fisher & Paykel Healthcare jumped 7 per cent to $17.08 after it upgraded its revenue and earnings guidance for the financial year ended 31 March 2020, after receiving regulatory clearance to sell its F &P Vitera mask in the United States.

Most miners were also strong, with BHP the best performer in terms of points as the iron ore miner added 7.8 points to the overall market advance with a 2 per cent gain to $36.53.

Rio Tinto shares climbed 2.2 per cent to $91.91 and Fortescue Metals rose 1.6 per cent to $8.95. South 32 shares were up 2 per cent to $2.50 over the session.

However, the gold miners were the market's key detractors. Newcrest Mining fell 4.8 per cent to $33.56, Northern Star dropped 5 per cent to $11.26, Evolution Minerals fell 5 per cent to $4.42.

In the telecom sector, Telstra dropped 1.7 per cent to $3.51 while supermarket operator Coles Group saw its shares decline 1.2 per cent to $15.19. CSL shares were down 0.3 per cent at $243.74.
description: "I think we will push to a new high," said Romano Sala Tenna, fund manager at Katana Asset Management. "It's definitely risk on."
